title: Field to Fork 2019: Best Management Practices to Produce More Potatoes

tasks.task: Conducting a detailed presentation on potato cultivation and best practices.
subtasks: Introducing Suzie Thompson, an associate professor and plant breeder at NDSU, and discussing her background in potato research and development.
Overviewing the botany and classification of potatoes, highlighting their origin in South American regions and their place in the Solanaceae family.
Presenting the market classes of potatoes, explaining their textures, storability, and culinary uses.
Discerning the nutritional benefits of potatoes, emphasizing low calorie content, high fiber, and potassium content compared to common beliefs.
Providing a historical account of potato breeding at NDSU, mentioning notable releases like Norland and Russet Norcota.
Discussing optimal growing conditions for potatoes, including temperature preferences, water requirements, and soil pH considerations.
Detailing propagation methods for potatoes, both asexual (conal propagation) and through true potato seed.
Offering spacing and planting depth guidelines for gardeners, emphasizing rows and hills formation for optimal growth.
Advising on fertilization techniques, emphasizing the significance of phosphorus for tuber production.
Explaining the process of hilling and its importance for water management and preventing greening.
Addressing common potato pests like Colorado potato beetles and managing leaf diseases such as early blight.
Discussing post-harvest care, including handling, storage conditions, and disease management like common scab.
Answering questions from the audience on topics ranging from seed potato selection to disease prevention and storage techniques.
